notesStmt.note: Title from caption and opening words of text.
Dated at end: Giuen at our palace of Westminster the seuenteenth day of December, in the foure and thirtieth yeere of our raigne.
Reproduction of original in the Society of Antiquaries Library, London, England.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ‚ùß By the Queene.
div.p: WHere it is ordained and prouided by a Statute, made and e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Parliament holden at We≈øtmin≈øter the eight day or Iune, in the eight and twentieth yeere of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øties dearely beloued father of famous memorie, King Henry the eight, that the prices of all kinde of Wines (that is to ≈øay) of the Tunne, Butte, Pipe, Punchion, Hog≈øheade, Tyer≈øe, Barrell and Bundlet, when it ≈øhould be ≈øolde in gro≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould be limitted and declared by the Lorde Chaunceller of England, Lord Trea≈øourer of England, Lorde Pre≈øident of the ≈øaide Kings mo≈øt honourable priuie Coun≈øell, Lorde prittie Seale, and the two chiefe Iu≈øtices of either Bench, or fiue, foure, or three of them, and that the ≈øame ≈øhould be ≈øolve according to the ≈øame prices ≈øo by them ≈øet and taxed, vpon paine and penaltie contained in the ≈øaid Acte: Fora≈ømuch as the Lord Crea≈øourer of England, and the two Lord chiefe Iu≈øtices, for diuers con≈øiderations them moouing, and according to the effect and meaning of the ≈øaid Statute and Acte, haue in writing by their deliberate adui≈øes, (vpon conference had with ≈øundrie per≈øons thereto requi≈øite,) tared, a≈ø≈øigned and appointed the prices of Ga≈øcoigne and French wines, to be ≈øolde within this her Highne≈ø≈øes Realme for this yeere folowing, in con≈øideration of the great charges for ≈øafe conduction of the Wines out of Fraunce (that is to ≈øay) euery Tunne of the be≈øt Ga≈øcoigne and French Wines to be ≈øolde (the ≈øeller bearing all the charges due and payable to her Maie≈øtie in her Cu≈øtome hou≈øe) after the rate and price of ≈øixteene Pounds ≈øterling the Tunn and not aboue: The byer bearing all the ≈øaid charges, after the price and rate of thirteene Pounds ≈øixe ≈øhillings eight pence ≈øterling the Tunne and not aboue. And euery Pipe, Butte, Hog≈øheade, Tyer≈øe, Barrell, Rundlet, and other ve≈ø≈øels of the ≈øame ≈øeuerall Wines to bee ≈øolde in gro≈ø≈øe after their quantities according to the ≈øame rates, and not aboue. And euery Tunne of Rochel and other ≈ømall and thinne Wines to be ≈øolde (the ≈øeller bearing all the charges due and payable to her Maie≈øtie in her Cu≈øtome hou≈øe) after the price and rate of foureteene Pounds ≈øixe ≈øhillings eight pence ≈øterling the Tunne, and not aboue: And the byer bearing the ≈øaid charges at axi. Pounds thirteene ≈øhillings foure pence ≈øterling the Tunne, and not aboue. And euery Butte, Pipe, Hog≈øhead, Tyer≈øe, Barrell, Rundlet, and other ve≈ø≈øels of the ≈øame ≈øeuerall Wines to bee ≈øolde in gro≈ø≈øe after their quantities according to the ≈øame rates, and not aboue. The Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie therefore ≈øtraightly chargeth and commaundeth all and ≈øinguler her louing Subiects and others, putting any maner Ga≈øcoigne, French, Rochell, or other ≈ømall or thinne Wines to ≈øale within this her Highne≈ø≈øe Realme, that they, nor any of them in any maner of wi≈øe by any craft, couin, or priuate agreement, ≈øhall ≈øell any Ga≈øcoigne, French, Rochel, or other ≈ømall or thinne Wines, otherwi≈øe then is aboue limitted, vpon paine to forfaite and pay ≈øuch penaltie as is conteined and expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid Statute, or in any other Statute made or ordained for the ≈øme.

And moreouer her Highne≈ø≈øe plea≈øure and commandement is, that all and ≈øinguler Maiors, Sheriffes, Bailiffes, Con≈øtables, and other officers to whom it apperteineth, that they and euery of them with diligence, cau≈øe and ≈øee that this her Proclamation be put in due execution after the tenour of the ≈øame, and al≈øo according to an other Act of Parliament e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Parliament aboue rehear≈øed, again≈øt ≈øuch as wil refu≈øe to ≈øell their Wines at prices taxed as is afore≈øaide, as they will an≈øwere thereto at their perils.
div.closer:
Giuen at our Palace of We≈øtmin≈øter the ≈øeuenteenth day of December, in the foure and thirtieth yeereof our Raigne.
God ≈øaue the Queene.

div.p: ‚ùß Imprinted at London by the Deputies of Chri≈øtopher Barker, Printer to Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie.
